poem_title: THE DIVERTING HISTORY OF JOHN GILPIN, SHEWING HOW HE WENT FARTHER THAN HE INTENDED AND CAME SAFE HOME AGAIN.
author: William Cowper

lines.line_text: JOHN Gilpin was a citizen
Of credit and renown,
A train-band Captain eke was he
Of famous London town.

stanzas.stanza_text:
JOHN Gilpin was a citizen
Of credit and renown,
A train-band Captain eke was he
Of famous London town.

lines.line_text: John Gilpin's spouse said to her dear,
Though wedded we have been
These twice ten tedious years, yet we
No holiday have seen.

stanzas.stanza_text:
John Gilpin's spouse said to her dear,
Though wedded we have been
These twice ten tedious years, yet we
No holiday have seen.

lines.line_text: To-morrow is our wedding-day,
And we will then repair
Unto the Bell at Edmonton
All in a chaise and pair.

stanzas.stanza_text:
To-morrow is our wedding-day,
And we will then repair
Unto the Bell at Edmonton
All in a chaise and pair.

lines.line_text: My sister and my sister's child,
My self and children three
Will fill the chaise, so you must ride
On horse-back after we.

stanzas.stanza_text:
My sister and my sister's child,
My self and children three
Will fill the chaise, so you must ride
On horse-back after we.

lines.line_text: He soon replied, I do admire
Of womankind but one,
And you are she, my dearest dear,
Therefore it shall be done.

stanzas.stanza_text:
He soon replied, I do admire
Of womankind but one,
And you are she, my dearest dear,
Therefore it shall be done.

lines.line_text: I am a linnen-draper bold,
As all the world doth know,
And my good friend the Callender
Will lend his horse to go.

stanzas.stanza_text:
I am a linnen-draper bold,
As all the world doth know,
And my good friend the Callender
Will lend his horse to go.

lines.line_text: Quoth Mrs. Gilpin, that's well said;
And for that wine is dear,
We will be furnish'd with our own,
Which is both bright and clear.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Quoth Mrs. Gilpin, that's well said;
And for that wine is dear,
We will be furnish'd with our own,
Which is both bright and clear.

lines.line_text: John Gilpin kiss'd his loving wife,
O'erjoy'd was he to find
That though on pleasure she was bent,
She had a frugal mind.

stanzas.stanza_text:
John Gilpin kiss'd his loving wife,
O'erjoy'd was he to find
That though on pleasure she was bent,
She had a frugal mind.

lines.line_text: The morning came, the chaise was brought,
But yet was not allow'd
To drive up to the door, lest all
Should say that she was proud.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The morning came, the chaise was brought,
But yet was not allow'd
To drive up to the door, lest all
Should say that she was proud.

lines.line_text: So three doors off the chaise was stay'd,
Where they did all get in,
Six precious souls, and all agog
To dash through thick and thin.

stanzas.stanza_text:
So three doors off the chaise was stay'd,
Where they did all get in,
Six precious souls, and all agog
To dash through thick and thin.

lines.line_text: Smack went the whip, round went the wheels,
Were never folk so glad,
The stones did rattle underneath
As if Cheapside were mad.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Smack went the whip, round went the wheels,
Were never folk so glad,
The stones did rattle underneath
As if Cheapside were mad.

lines.line_text: John Gilpin at his horse's side
Seized fast the flowing main,
And up he got in haste to ride,
But soon came down again.

stanzas.stanza_text:
John Gilpin at his horse's side
Seized fast the flowing main,
And up he got in haste to ride,
But soon came down again.

lines.line_text: For saddle-tree scarce reach'd had he,
His journey to begin,
When turning round his head he saw
Three customers come in.

stanzas.stanza_text:
For saddle-tree scarce reach'd had he,
His journey to begin,
When turning round his head he saw
Three customers come in.

lines.line_text: So down he came, for loss of time
Although it grieved him sore,
Yet loss of pence, full well he knew,
Would trouble him much more:

stanzas.stanza_text:
So down he came, for loss of time
Although it grieved him sore,
Yet loss of pence, full well he knew,
Would trouble him much more:

lines.line_text: 'Twas long before the customers
Were suited to their mind,
When Betty screaming came down stairs,
"The wine is left behind."

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Twas long before the customers
Were suited to their mind,
When Betty screaming came down stairs,
"The wine is left behind."

lines.line_text: Good lack! quoth he, yet bring it me,
My leathern belt likewise
In which I bear my trusty sword
When I do exercise.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Good lack! quoth he, yet bring it me,
My leathern belt likewise
In which I bear my trusty sword
When I do exercise.

lines.line_text: Now Mistress Gilpin, careful soul,
Had two stone bottles found,
To hold the liquor that she loved,
And keep it safe and sound.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now Mistress Gilpin, careful soul,
Had two stone bottles found,
To hold the liquor that she loved,
And keep it safe and sound.

lines.line_text: Each bottle had a curling ear
Through which the belt he drew,
And hung a bottle on each side
To make his balance true.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Each bottle had a curling ear
Through which the belt he drew,
And hung a bottle on each side
To make his balance true.

lines.line_text: Then over all, that he might be
Equipp'd from top to toe,
His long red cloak well brush'd and neat
He manfully did throw.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Then over all, that he might be
Equipp'd from top to toe,
His long red cloak well brush'd and neat
He manfully did throw.

lines.line_text: Now see him mounted once again
Upon his nimble steed,
Full slowly pacing o'er the stones
With caution and good heed.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now see him mounted once again
Upon his nimble steed,
Full slowly pacing o'er the stones
With caution and good heed.

lines.line_text: But finding soon a smoother road
Beneath his well-shod feet,
The snorting beast began to trot,
Which gall'd him in his seat.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But finding soon a smoother road
Beneath his well-shod feet,
The snorting beast began to trot,
Which gall'd him in his seat.

lines.line_text: So fair and softly, John he cried,
But John he cried in vain,
That trot became a gallop soon
In spite of curb and rein.

stanzas.stanza_text:
So fair and softly, John he cried,
But John he cried in vain,
That trot became a gallop soon
In spite of curb and rein.

lines.line_text: So stooping down, as needs he must
Who cannot sit upright,
He grasp'd the mane with both his hands
And eke with all his might.

stanzas.stanza_text:
So stooping down, as needs he must
Who cannot sit upright,
He grasp'd the mane with both his hands
And eke with all his might.

lines.line_text: His horse who never in that sort
Had handled been before,
What thing upon his back had got
Did wonder more and more.

stanzas.stanza_text:
His horse who never in that sort
Had handled been before,
What thing upon his back had got
Did wonder more and more.

lines.line_text: Away went Gilpin neck or nought,
Away went hat and wig,
He little dreamt when he set out
Of running such a rig.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Away went Gilpin neck or nought,
Away went hat and wig,
He little dreamt when he set out
Of running such a rig.

lines.line_text: The wind did blow, the cloak did fly,
Like streamer long and gay,
'Till loop and button failing both
At last it flew away.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The wind did blow, the cloak did fly,
Like streamer long and gay,
'Till loop and button failing both
At last it flew away.

lines.line_text: Then might all people well discern
The bottles he had flung,
A bottle swinging at each side
As hath been said or sung.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Then might all people well discern
The bottles he had flung,
A bottle swinging at each side
As hath been said or sung.

lines.line_text: The dogs did bark, the children scream'd;
Up flew the windows all,
And ev'ry soul cried out, well done,
As loud as he could bawl.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The dogs did bark, the children scream'd;
Up flew the windows all,
And ev'ry soul cried out, well done,
As loud as he could bawl.

lines.line_text: Away went Gilpin  who but he;
His fame soon spread around
He carries weight, he rides a race,
'Tis for a thousand pound.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Away went Gilpin  who but he;
His fame soon spread around 
He carries weight, he rides a race,
'Tis for a thousand pound.

lines.line_text: And still as fast as he drew near,
'Twas wonderful to view
How in a trice the turnpike-men
Their gates wide open threw:

stanzas.stanza_text:
And still as fast as he drew near,
'Twas wonderful to view
How in a trice the turnpike-men
Their gates wide open threw:

lines.line_text: And now as he went bowing down
His reeking head full low,
The bottles twain behind his back
Were shatter'd at a blow.

stanzas.stanza_text:
And now as he went bowing down
His reeking head full low,
The bottles twain behind his back
Were shatter'd at a blow.

lines.line_text: Down ran the wine into the road
Most piteous to be seen,
Which made his horse's flanks to smoke
As they had basted been.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Down ran the wine into the road
Most piteous to be seen,
Which made his horse's flanks to smoke
As they had basted been.

lines.line_text: But still he seem'd to carry weight,
With leathern girdle braced,
For all might see the bottle necks
Still dangling at his waist.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But still he seem'd to carry weight,
With leathern girdle braced,
For all might see the bottle necks
Still dangling at his waist.

lines.line_text: Thus all through merry Islington
These gambols he did play,
And till he came unto the wash
Of Edmonton so gay.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Thus all through merry Islington
These gambols he did play,
And till he came unto the wash
Of Edmonton so gay.

lines.line_text: And there he threw the wash about
On both sides of the way,
Just like unto a trundling mop,
Or a wild-goose at play.

stanzas.stanza_text:
And there he threw the wash about
On both sides of the way,
Just like unto a trundling mop,
Or a wild-goose at play.

lines.line_text: At Edmonton his loving wife
From the balcony spied
Her tender husband, wond'ring much
To see how he did ride.

stanzas.stanza_text:
At Edmonton his loving wife
From the balcony spied
Her tender husband, wond'ring much
To see how he did ride.

lines.line_text: Stop, stop John Gilpin!  Here's the house
They all at once did cry,
The dinner waits and we are tir'd,
Said Gilpin  so am I.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Stop, stop John Gilpin!  Here's the house 
They all at once did cry,
The dinner waits and we are tir'd,
Said Gilpin  so am I.

lines.line_text: But yet his horse was not a whit
Inclined to tarry there,
For why? his owner had a house
Full ten miles off at Ware.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But yet his horse was not a whit
Inclined to tarry there,
For why? his owner had a house
Full ten miles off at Ware.

lines.line_text: So like an arrow swift he flew
Shot by an archer strong,
So did he fly  which brings me to
The middle of my song.

stanzas.stanza_text:
So like an arrow swift he flew
Shot by an archer strong,
So did he fly  which brings me to
The middle of my song.

lines.line_text: Away went Gilpin, out of breath,
And sore against his will,
Till at his friend's the Callender's
His horse at last stood still.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Away went Gilpin, out of breath,
And sore against his will,
Till at his friend's the Callender's
His horse at last stood still.

lines.line_text: The Callender amazed to see
His neighbour in such trim,
Laid down his pipe, flew to the gate,
And thus accosted him.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Callender amazed to see
His neighbour in such trim,
Laid down his pipe, flew to the gate,
And thus accosted him.

lines.line_text: What news, what news, your tidings tell,
Tell me you must and shall
Say why bare headed you are come,
Or why you come at all.

stanzas.stanza_text:
What news, what news, your tidings tell,
Tell me you must and shall 
Say why bare headed you are come,
Or why you come at all.

lines.line_text: Now Gilpin had a pleasant wit
And loved a timely joke,
And thus unto the Callender
In merry guise he spoke.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now Gilpin had a pleasant wit
And loved a timely joke,
And thus unto the Callender
In merry guise he spoke.

lines.line_text: I came because your horse would come,
And if I well forebode,
My hat and wig will soon be here,
They are upon the road.

stanzas.stanza_text:
I came because your horse would come,
And if I well forebode,
My hat and wig will soon be here,
They are upon the road.

lines.line_text: The Callender right glad to find
His friend in merry pin,
Return'd him not a single word,
But to the house went in.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Callender right glad to find
His friend in merry pin,
Return'd him not a single word,
But to the house went in.

lines.line_text: Whence strait he came with hat and wig,
A wig that flow'd behind,
A hat not much the worse for wear,
Each comely in its kind.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Whence strait he came with hat and wig,
A wig that flow'd behind,
A hat not much the worse for wear,
Each comely in its kind.

lines.line_text: He held them up, and in his turn
Thus show'd his ready wit,
My head is twice as big as yours,
They therefore needs must fit.

stanzas.stanza_text:
He held them up, and in his turn
Thus show'd his ready wit,
My head is twice as big as yours,
They therefore needs must fit.

lines.line_text: But let me scrape the dirt away
That hangs upon your face,
And stop and eat, for well you may
Be in a hungry case.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But let me scrape the dirt away
That hangs upon your face,
And stop and eat, for well you may
Be in a hungry case.

lines.line_text: Said John, it is my wedding-day,
And all the world would stare,
If wife should dine at Edmonton
And I should dine at Ware.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Said John, it is my wedding-day,
And all the world would stare,
If wife should dine at Edmonton
And I should dine at Ware.

lines.line_text: So turning to his horse, he said,
I am in haste to dine,
'Twas for your pleasure you came here,
You shall go back for mine.

stanzas.stanza_text:
So turning to his horse, he said,
I am in haste to dine,
'Twas for your pleasure you came here,
You shall go back for mine.

lines.line_text: Ah luckless speech, and bootless boast!
For which he paid full dear,
For while he spake a braying ass
Did sing most loud and clear.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Ah luckless speech, and bootless boast!
For which he paid full dear,
For while he spake a braying ass
Did sing most loud and clear.

lines.line_text: Whereat his horse did snort as he
Had heard a lion roar,
And gallop'd off with all his might
As he had done before.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Whereat his horse did snort as he
Had heard a lion roar,
And gallop'd off with all his might
As he had done before.

lines.line_text: Away went Gilpin and away
Went Gilpin's hat and wig;
He lost them sooner than at first,
For why? they were too big.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Away went Gilpin and away
Went Gilpin's hat and wig;
He lost them sooner than at first,
For why? they were too big.

lines.line_text: Now, Mistress Gilpin when she saw,
Her husband posting down
Into the country far away,
She pull'd out half a crown.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now, Mistress Gilpin when she saw,
Her husband posting down
Into the country far away,
She pull'd out half a crown.

lines.line_text: And thus unto the youth she said
That drove them to the Bell,
This shall be yours when you bring back
My husband safe and well.

stanzas.stanza_text:
And thus unto the youth she said
That drove them to the Bell,
This shall be yours when you bring back
My husband safe and well.

lines.line_text: The youth did ride, and soon did meet
John coming back amain,
Whom in a trice he tried to stop
By catching at his rein.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The youth did ride, and soon did meet
John coming back amain,
Whom in a trice he tried to stop
By catching at his rein.

lines.line_text: But not performing what he meant
And gladly would have done,
The frighted steed he frighted more,
And made him faster run.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But not performing what he meant
And gladly would have done,
The frighted steed he frighted more,
And made him faster run.

lines.line_text: Away went Gilpin, and away
Went post-boy at his heels,
The post-boy's horse right glad to miss
The lumb'ring of the wheels.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Away went Gilpin, and away
Went post-boy at his heels,
The post-boy's horse right glad to miss
The lumb'ring of the wheels.

lines.line_text: Six gentlemen upon the road
Thus seeing Gilpin fly,
With post-boy scamp'ring in the rear,
They rais'd the hue and cry.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Six gentlemen upon the road
Thus seeing Gilpin fly,
With post-boy scamp'ring in the rear,
They rais'd the hue and cry.

lines.line_text: Stop thief, stop thief  a highwayman!
Not one of them was mute,
And all and each that pass'd that way
Did join in the pursuit.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Stop thief, stop thief  a highwayman!
Not one of them was mute,
And all and each that pass'd that way
Did join in the pursuit.

lines.line_text: And now the turnpike gates again
Flew open in short space,
The toll-men thinking as before
That Gilpin rode a race.

stanzas.stanza_text:
And now the turnpike gates again
Flew open in short space,
The toll-men thinking as before
That Gilpin rode a race.

lines.line_text: And so he did and won it too,
For he got first to town,
Nor stopp'd 'till where he had got up
He did again get down.

stanzas.stanza_text:
And so he did and won it too,
For he got first to town,
Nor stopp'd 'till where he had got up
He did again get down.

lines.line_text: Now let us sing, long live the king,
And Gilpin long live he,
And when he next doth ride abroad,
May I be there to see!

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now let us sing, long live the king,
And Gilpin long live he,
And when he next doth ride abroad,
May I be there to see!
